other_notes:
Ord writes: "Don’t take these numbers to be completely objective. [...] And don’t take the estimates to be precise. Their purpose is to show the right order of magnitude, rather than a more precise probability."

This estimate already incorporates Ord's expectation that people will start taking these risks more seriously in future. For his "business as usual" estimate, see the conditional estimates sheet.
This is the median. The report about these estimates also plots the results for each question “with individual response distributions visible” in Appendix A.

estimation_measure: Risk of extinction over the next five centuries
other_notes: "The probability of the human race avoiding extinction for the next five centuries is encouragingly high, perhaps as high as 70 percent”
source: Leslie, J. (1996). The End of the World: the science and ethics of human extinction.

estimation_measure: Odds that our present civilization on earth will survive to the end of the present century
source: Rees, M. J. (2003). Our final century. Basic Books

estimation_measure: "there be zero living humans on planet earth on January 1, 2100"
other_notes: That median and mean is as of 3rd July 2019.

estimation_measure: The prior probability that "humanity will cease to exist before 5,100 years or thrive beyond 7.8 million years" (quote from Beard et al.'s appendix)
source: Gott III, J. R. (1993). Implications of the Copernican principle for our future prospects. Nature, 363, 315-319.

estimation_measure: Annual probability as of 2009 of extinction
source: Wells, W. (2009) Human survivability. In: Apocalypse When?. Springer Praxis Books. Praxis https://doi.org/10.1007/978-0-387-09837-1_5

estimation_measure: “Humanity’s prognosis for the coming century is well approximated by a global catastrophic risk of 0.2% per year.”
other_notes: Beard et al. seem to imply this is about extinction, but the quote suggests it's about "global catastrophic risk".
source: Simpson, F. (2016). Apocalypse now? Reviving the Doomsday argument. arXiv preprint arXiv:1611.03072.

estimation_measure: “Humanity avoids every existential catastrophe and eventually fulfils its potential: achieving something close to the best future open to us”
"Personally, I now think we humans will be wiped out this century"
source: William Poundstone, The Doomsday Calculation, p. 259

estimation_measure: "sentient life will survive for at least billions of years"
other_notes: "I think it's fairly likely(>20%) that sentient life will survive for at least billions of years; and that there may be a fair amount of lock-in, so changing the trajectory of things could be great."

estimator: I will not report the number from Stern Review: The economics of climate change, as it was not actually meant as an estimate.
